{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12741,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Athyrium distentifolium, or alpine lady fern, thrives in moist environments. Water the plant regularly to ensure the soil remains consistently damp, but not waterlogged. During the growing season, make sure the soil is always moist, checking every few days to maintain the appropriate moisture level. In winter, reduce watering slightly but never allow the soil to completely dry out as this can damage the plant. Use rainwater or distilled water if possible since this plant prefers soft water without added minerals."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Athyrium distentifolium prefers partial to full shade environments, mimicking its natural forest understory habitat. Direct sunlight can harm the delicate fronds, so it's best to place this plant in shaded areas, such as under larger plants or trees. If grown indoors, position the fern in a location that receives filtered or indirect sunlight, such as near a north-facing window. Providing sufficient shade will help maintain its vibrant green color and prevent frond scorching and stress to the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Athyrium distentifolium is minimal and mainly involves removing dead or damaged fronds to encourage the growth of new shoots. It's best to prune in late winter or early spring before the growing season begins. Use clean, sterile pruning shears to prevent the spread of disease, and cut the fronds at the base. Regularly removing old growth will also help maintain the aesthetic appeal of the fern and prevent any potential overcrowding at the plant's base, promoting better air circulation."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Alpine Lady-fern","description":"Athyrium distentifolium commonly known as alpine lady-fern is a fern found in widely in the Northern Hemisphere.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Alpine Lady-fern"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Division"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Athyrium distentifolium"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13039,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ericameria parishii, commonly known as Parish's goldenbush, requires minimal watering once it is established, as it is drought-tolerant. Water this plant sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot and other issues. During its initial growth period after planting, it may need more frequent watering until its root system is established, usually the first one or two growing seasons. Beyond this period, rainfall is often sufficient to meet its water needs, except during prolonged dry spells when occasional deep watering may be necessary."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ericameria parishii thrives in full sun, needing at least six hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth. This exposure ensures the production of vibrant, healthy foliage and encourages abundant flowering. While it can tolerate some light shade, insufficient sunlight may result in leggy growth and reduced flowering. Planting in an area with full sun ensures the best possible conditions for its growth. If grown indoors or in a partially shaded area, consider supplementing with a grow light to meet its sunlight needs."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ericameria parishii is generally minimal and should focus on maintaining its shape and health. It is best to prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to improve air circulation and encourage healthy growth. Light pruning can help maintain a compact shape, as this plant can become leggy with sparse growth if left unpruned. Avoid heavy pruning, as it may stress the plant and affect blooming. Always use clean, sharp tools to minimize harm to the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Parish's Rabbitbrush","description":"Ericameria parishii (Parish's rabbitbrush) is a western North American species of flowering plants in the daisy family.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Western United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Parish's Rabbitbrush"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Ericameria parishii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13638,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Solanum dimidiatum, commonly known as Western Horse Nettle, prefers well-drained soil and does not need frequent watering once established. Watering needs can vary based on climate conditions, but generally, you should allow the soil to dry out between waterings. It can tolerate drought conditions fairly well. Overwatering can be detrimental, so ensure that the plant does not sit in waterlogged soil, as this can lead to root rot. During its active growing periods in the spring and summer, monitoring the moisture level and adjusting watering frequency is key."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Solanum dimidiatum thrives in full sunlight and is well-suited to areas that receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day. While it can tolerate partial shade, inadequate light can result in reduced flowering and leggy growth. The plant's natural habitat in open fields and prairies indicates a preference for sunny, open environments. Providing ample sunlight will ensure robust growth and plentiful blooms, contributing to the health and vitality of the plant. Keep it in a location where it can maximize sunshine exposure for best results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Solanum dimidiatum is generally minimal; however, it may be necessary to remove any dead or diseased stems to promote healthier growth. If the plant becomes leggy, you can trim back some of the longer stems to encourage bushier growth. Late winter or early spring is typically the best time to perform any pruning. Be sure to wear gloves when handling the plant, as its spiny stems can be irritating to the skin. Regular inspection can help manage its spread and keep it from becoming invasive in garden settings."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"western horsenettle","description":"Solanum dimidiatum is a species of nightshade known by the common names western horsenettle, Torrey's nightshade, and robust horsenettle. It is native to the central United States, where it grows in many types of habitat, including disturbed areas. In California it is known as an introduced species and a noxious weed. It is a rhizomatous perennial herb producing an erect stem up to 80 centimeters tall. It is covered in yellow prickles and branched hairs. The...","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Southern USA","Mexico"],"other_name":["western horsenettle"],"pest_susceptibility":["Leaf miners","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Solanum dimidiatum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12540,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Prunus amygdalus, commonly known as the almond tree, prefers moderate watering. In general, water the tree deeply once or twice a week during dry periods, ensuring the soil is kept moist but not waterlogged. Almond trees benefit from a consistent watering schedule, especially during the first few years after planting to establish a strong root system. Overwatering or allowing the roots to sit in water can lead to root rot and other issues. Reduce watering during the tree's dormant period in the winter. Always adjust watering based on local rainfall and humidity levels."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Prunus amygdalus thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day. Almond trees need ample sunlight to produce an abundance of flowers and fruit. Planting them in a location where they can receive unobstructed sun exposure is crucial for optimal growth and nut production. While they can tolerate some light shade, insufficient sunlight will lead to poor flowering and fruiting. Additionally, ensure they are planted in well-drained soil to maximize their growth potential with the sunlight they receive. Keep them away from structures or other trees that may block sunlight."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning almond trees is essential for their health and productivity. Prune during their dormant season, usually in late winter, before new growth begins. Focus on removing any dead, diseased, or damaged branches, as well as any crossing or crowded branches that can obstruct sunlight and air circulation. Additionally, prune to shape the tree, encouraging an open center that allows light penetration, which is crucial for fruit production. Regularly trimming the tips of branches can also stimulate branching and increase yield. Always use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts and prevent damage to the tree."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Almond","description":"The almond (Prunus dulcis, syn. Prunus amygdalus) is a species of tree native to Iran and surrounding countries but widely cultivated elsewhere. The almond is also the name of the edible and widely cultivated seed of this tree. Within the genus Prunus, it is classified with the peach in the subgenus Amygdalus, distinguished from the other subgenera by corrugations on the shell (endocarp) surrounding the seed.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Iran","Central Asia"],"other_name":["Almond"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Shot hole disease","Anthracnose"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Grafting Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Prunus amygdalus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14029,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Picea mariana, or black spruce, prefers consistently moist, well-drained soil. It typically thrives in its native environments of bogs and swamps, where moisture levels are high. When grown in cultivation, ensure the soil does not dry out completely, especially during dry spells or hot summer months. It is important to provide a supplementary watering if natural rainfall is insufficient, ensuring that the root zone remains evenly moist. However, avoid waterlogging the soil since poor drainage can lead to root rot. A layer of mulch can help retain soil moisture and regulate temperature."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Black spruce is adaptable to a range of light conditions, but for optimal growth, it prefers full sun. This means it requires at least six hours of direct, unobstructed sunlight each day. While it can tolerate some partial shade, especially in its natural habitat where it may benefit from surrounding taller trees, sufficient sunlight is essential for healthy, vigorous growth. In insufficient light conditions, the plant may experience slower growth and a thinner crown. Therefore, planting it in a sunny, open area is ideal for achieving the best results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Picea mariana should be minimal and is generally only necessary to remove dead or damaged branches. This should be done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. When pruning, make clean cuts just outside the branch collar to promote proper healing. Avoid cutting the central leader, as this could alter the tree's natural shape. Additionally, if you are growing black spruce for its compact form or as a part of a landscape design, you may selectively trim to maintain desired shapes, but always be cautious not to remove too much foliage."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"black spruce","description":"Picea mariana, the black spruce, is a North American species of spruce tree in the pine family. It is widespread across Canada, found in all 10 provinces and all 3 Arctic territories. Its range extends into northern parts of the United States: in Alaska, the Great Lakes region, and the upper Northeast. It is a frequent part of the biome known as taiga or boreal forest.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Canada","United States"],"other_name":["black spruce"],"pest_susceptibility":["Spruce budworm"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Picea mariana"],"soil":["Acidic","Loamy","Wet"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12148,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Persea americana, known commonly as the avocado tree, requires consistent and deep watering, especially during the growing season. The soil should be well-draining to avoid roots sitting in water, which can lead to rot. It's best to water the tree deeply every 1-2 weeks, allowing the soil to dry out between sessions. Younger trees need more frequent watering compared to mature ones. During the dormant season, typically in the cooler months, reduce watering but ensure the soil remains slightly moist, as drought stress can affect fruit production and tree health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Avocado trees thrive in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. They prefer a position that is sheltered from strong winds while still receiving ample sunlight. If growing indoors or in a less sunny climate, consider placing the tree near a large, south-facing window to maximize light exposure. Insufficient sunlight can lead to poor growth and reduced fruit production. However, in extremely hot climates, some light afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorching. Always monitor the plant's response to adjust light conditions accordingly."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning an avocado tree should be done to remove dead or damaged limbs, maintain its shape, and improve light penetration and air circulation. It's best to prune the tree in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Keep the tree at a manageable height to ease harvesting and care. Remove crossing branches and those growing inward to open the canopy. Be cautious not to over-prune, as excessive removal of leaves can reduce fruit production. Pruning also helps in stimulating new growth, which is vital for fruiting."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Avocado","description":"The avocado (Persea americana) is a tree, long thought to have originated in South Central Mexico, classified as a member of the flowering plant family Lauraceae. Recent archaeological research produced evidence that the avocado was present in Peru as long as 8,000 to 15,000 years ago. Avocado (also alligator pear) refers to the tree's fruit, which is botanically a large berry containing a single large seed.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico","Central America"],"other_name":["Avocado"],"pest_susceptibility":["Anthracnose","Root rot","Verticillium wilt"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Grafting Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Persea americana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12343,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Calochortus bruneaunis, commonly known as the Bruneau mariposa lily, requires careful watering, especially during its active growing season in spring and early summer. It prefers well-drained soil and should not be overwatered, as it is susceptible to bulb rot. It's best to water moderately when the top couple of inches of the soil feel dry. As the plant enters dormancy after flowering, reduce watering significantly and allow the soil to dry out almost completely. This mimics its natural habitat, where it experiences dry summers."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Calochortus bruneaunis thrives in full sunlight, so it should be planted in an area where it receives at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13536,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ranunculus aquatilis, also known as water crowfoot, grows in aquatic environments and does not need traditional watering like most plants. Instead, it thrives when submerged in water, either in ponds, aquariums, or natural water bodies. Ensure that the water is clean and maintain a consistent water level to support healthy growth. In container setups, water should be changed periodically to prevent stagnation and maintain oxygenation, which is crucial for the plant's health. However, be mindful of any growth restrictions placed by certain zones to prevent excessive spreading in natural habitats."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ranunculus aquatilis typically prefers a good balance of light and shade. Ideal conditions involve bright, indirect sunlight, which mimics its natural habitat where sunlight filters through water. If grown in an aquarium or pond, positioning it in an area with plenty of daylight but avoiding direct, harsh sunlight will prevent leaf burn. In shaded aquatic environments, ensure there is some dappled sunlight throughout the day for optimal growth. Monitor for signs of too much or too little light, adjusting the plant’s exposure accordingly by relocating it or adding shade if needed."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Ranunculus aquatilis mainly involves managing its growth to avoid excessive proliferation. Regularly check for damaged or dying leaves and stems, snipping them away with clean scissors or pruning shears to maintain health and aesthetics. Trimming may also be necessary to control its spread, especially in smaller water features or aquariums. Removing excess organic material can prevent decomposition, which could otherwise affect water quality. Be cautious in natural waterways, as it is considered invasive in some regions, ensuring that removed plant material is adequately disposed of to not promote unintentional growth elsewhere."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"common water-crowfoot","description":"Ranunculus aquatilis, the common water-crowfoot or white water-crowfoot, is a plant species of the genus Ranunculus, native throughout most of Europe and western North America, and also northwest Africa.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia","North America"],"other_name":["common water-crowfoot"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Ranunculus aquatilis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Wet","Clay","Loamy","Sandy","Silt"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

When planted in shadier locations, it might experience reduced flowering and leggy growth, so ensure it receives sufficient sunlight. While it can tolerate partial shade, placing it in a spot with morning sun and afternoon shade can also work well, especially in warmer climates. This balance allows the plant to flourish without becoming stressed from excessive heat or insufficient light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Agrimonia striata is generally minimal. It can be done to regulate growth or remove dead and damaged leaves to maintain plant health. The best time to prune is in early spring before new growth starts, or after it has finished blooming to clean up the plant. Trim back spent flower stalks and dead foliage to encourage a tidy appearance. Cutting back stems can also help promote dense growth and a fuller plant, but heavy pruning is rarely needed, as the plant maintains a natural form with minimal grooming."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"roadside agrimony","description":"Agrimonia striata (roadside agrimony, grooved agrimony, agrimony, cocklebur, woodland agrimony, woodland grooveburr) is a species of perennial forb belonging to the rose family (Rosaceae). It is native to the United States, Canada, and Saint Pierre and Miquelon.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["roadside agrimony"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Agrimonia striata"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12241,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Solanum torvum, commonly known as turkey berry, requires moderate watering to thrive. It is important to keep the soil consistently moist, but not waterlogged, to avoid root rot. Water the plant deeply once every week, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. Make adjustments according to seasonal variations; reduce frequency in cooler months as the plant's water needs decrease. Ensure proper drainage in the pot or ground to prevent water accumulation. Observing the plant's leaves will help in assessing its water needs; drooping leaves can indicate it's time to water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Solanum torvum thrives in full sun, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day. This exposure ensures proper fruiting and robust growth. If growing indoors, place the plant near a south or west-facing window where it can receive adequate light. For outdoor planting, choose a location that is not shaded by taller plants or structures. While it can tolerate partial shade, extended periods of low light can result in weak or leggy growth and reduced fruit production. Ensuring an optimal light environment will support its health and productivity."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Solanum torvum helps manage its growth and encourages a healthy structure. It should be pruned regularly to remove dead or damaged branches, as well as any suckers that appear at the base to promote air circulation within the bush. Use sharp, sterile pruning shears to make clean cuts just above a node or leaf joint. The best time for pruning is during the plant's dormant period in late winter or early spring. This also helps prepare the plant for vigorous growth in the upcoming season. Pruning can also keep the plant manageable in size and shape."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Turkey Berry","description":"Solanum torvum is a bushy, erect and spiny perennial plant used horticulturally as a rootstock for eggplant. Pruning helps to maintain the plant's shape and encourages denser growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"white turtlehead","description":"Chelone glabra (white turtlehead) is an herbaceous species of plant native to North America. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13738,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Vancouveria hexandra, commonly known as inside-out flower, thrives best in consistently moist soil. It prefers well-drained soil and benefits from regular watering to maintain slight moisture around the roots, but ensure not to overwater as this can lead to root rot. During dry periods, more frequent watering may be required to mimic its natural moist woodland habitat. Reduce watering in the late fall and winter seasons since the plant enters a dormancy phase and requires less water during this time. Always let the top soil dry out slightly before the next watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Vancouveria hexandra prefers shaded to partially shaded environments, reflecting its native woodland surroundings. It thrives under dappled sunlight or partial shade, receiving only indirect light, as harsh direct sunlight can damage the foliage, leading to scorched leaves. Providing filtered sunlight under trees or near a north or east-facing wall is ideal. This plant can tolerate full shade, though this may result in reduced blooming. If growing indoors, place it near a window where it can receive indirect sunlight for several hours a day for optimal growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Vancouveria hexandra is largely unnecessary as it maintains a tidy growth habit naturally. However, removing any dead or damaged foliage is beneficial to promote healthier growth. You should prune spent flower stems to encourage more blooms and reduce potential seed spread if not desired. Conduct any light pruning in early spring before the growing season begins to maintain bushiness and encourage new growth. Avoid heavy pruning as it can stress the plant and disrupt its natural growing pattern. Regularly check for damaged parts and trim as needed."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"White Inside-out Flower","description":"Vancouveria hexandra, the white inside-out flower, is a perennial herb in the barberry family Berberidaceae. Regular light pruning can be used to manage size and remove any stray or overgrown branches."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Desert Holly","description":"Atriplex hymenelytra, or desert holly, is silvery-whitish-gray shrub in the goosefoot family (Chenopodiaceae), native to southwestern United States deserts.:141:271 It is the most drought tolerant saltbush in North America. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12442,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Abies magnifica, commonly known as the California red fir, prefers consistently moist but well-drained soil. It is crucial to avoid waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. During its establishment phase, regular watering is essential, especially during dry spells. Once established, the tree becomes more drought-tolerant but should still be watered during prolonged dry periods. Always check the top few inches of soil; if it feels dry to touch, it’s time to water. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture, but ensure that the mulch does not touch the trunk directly."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Abies magnifica thrives best in full sunlight to partial shade settings. Ideally, it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight daily to support optimal growth and health. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can prevent excessive heat stress. While this plant can tolerate partial shade, its growth may be slower and less symmetrical compared to those grown in full sun. Positioning the tree in an area with adequate air circulation and avoiding overly dense shade will help prevent issues such as mold or mildew on needles."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Abies magnifica should be minimal as it naturally forms a symmetrical shape. However, you can remove dead, diseased, or damaged branches at any time of the year to maintain tree health. If shaping is necessary, do so during the dormant winter months to minimize the risk of sap loss and stress on the plant. When pruning, make clean cuts near the base of the stem or branch without leaving stubs. Regularly inspect the tree to catch any unhealthy growth early, as this species generally does not require frequent cutting back."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"red fir","description":"Abies magnifica, the red fir or silvertip fir, is a western North American fir, native to the mountains of southwest Oregon and California in the United States. It is a high elevation tree, typically occurring at 1,400–2,700 metres (4,600–8,900 ft) elevation, though only rarely reaching tree line. The name red fir derives from the bark color of old trees.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["California","Oregon"],"other_name":["red fir"],"pest_susceptibility":["Heart rot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Abies magnifica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13937,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Fraxinus angustifolia, or the narrow-leafed ash, is a moisture-loving tree and prefers consistent watering, especially in dry conditions. Ensure the soil remains moderately moist but not waterlogged. Young trees require regular watering to establish a healthy root system, approximately once a week during the growing season. Mature trees can tolerate short periods of drought, but consistent deep watering during prolonged dry spells will benefit their health and growth. It is important to adjust watering frequency based on the soil type and local climate conditions, ensuring the water penetrates the soil deeply to reach the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Fraxinus angustifolia thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. It requires at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily to maintain vigorous growth and a healthy foliage canopy. While it can tolerate partial shade, optimal sunlight exposure ensures robust growth and helps the tree build resistance to pests and diseases. When planting, choose a site with ample sunlight for the best growth performance. If sunlight is limited, ensure the location gets the most direct sunlight available during the day, particularly in the morning and early afternoon hours."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Fraxinus angustifolia is essential to maintain its structure and health. Prune in late winter or early spring to shape the tree and remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches. This promotes good airflow and reduces disease risks. Focus on removing branches that are weak or may cause overcrowding within the tree's canopy. Be cautious to avoid excessive pruning as ash trees naturally have an open canopy. Avoid pruning in late summer or fall to prevent stimulating new growth that could be damaged by early frost. Regular pruning ensures a strong framework and aesthetically pleasing shape."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Narrow-leaved Ash","description":"Fraxinus angustifolia (narrow-leafed ash) is a species of Fraxinus native to central and southern Europe, northwest Africa, and southwest Asia.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","North Africa","Western Asia"],"other_name":["Narrow-leaved Ash"],"pest_susceptibility":["Ash dieback","Emerald ash borer"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Fraxinus angustifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In hot, dry weather, it may need water more frequently, possibly every other day, to prevent wilting. The soil should never completely dry out. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and regulate temperature. During the dormancy period in winter, reduce watering and allow the soil to dry out somewhat between waterings. Over-watering in winter can lead to root rot and other fungal problems."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hibiscus moscheutos requires full sunlight for optimal growth and blooming. Ideally, it should receive at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight each day. The plant is tolerant of partial shade but may produce fewer flowers if not provided with sufficient sunlight. Morning sunlight is particularly beneficial as it helps to dry off early morning dew, reducing the risk of fungal diseases. If planted in a particularly hot and dry climate, some afternoon shade might be beneficial to prevent the foliage from scorching, but generally, full sun conditions will yield the best results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Hibiscus moscheutos is essential for maintaining its shape and encouraging new growth. It's best to prune in early spring, just as new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged stems to improve health and appearance. Trim the stems back to about 12-18 inches above the ground to encourage bushiness and more blooms during the summer. Regular deadheading of spent flowers throughout the blooming season can also help prolong blooming periods. At the end of the growing season, you may choose to cut the plant back to the ground once it has entered dormancy after the first hard frost."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"swamp rose mallow","description":"Hibiscus moscheutos (rose mallow, swamp rose-mallow, crimsoneyed rosemallow, eastern rosemallow) is a species of flowering plant in the family Malvaceae. It is a cold-hardy perennial wetland plant that can grow in large colonies. The hirsute leaves are of variable morphology, but are commonly deltoidal in shape with up to three lobes. It is found in wetlands and along the riverine systems of the southeastern United States from Texas to the Atlantic states, its territory extending northward...","family":null,"flower_color":"Red, White, Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["swamp rose mallow"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Japanese beetles","Spider mites","Whiteflies"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Hibiscus moscheutos"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

However, since it relies on its host for sustenance, the sunlight requirements align more with the host plant's needs than its own specific needs."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Cuscuta campestris is usually not recommended or necessary for its own care since it is considered a parasitic plant often invasive in gardens and crops. Instead, controlling its growth is more common, often requiring removal if it spreads excessively or becomes detrimental to the host plant's health. In environments where it's cultivated or monitored, some might trim excess growth primarily to manage spread rather than for the health of the dodder itself."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Field Dodder","description":"Cuscuta campestris, with the common names field dodder, golden dodder, large-seeded alfalfa dodder, yellow dodder and prairie dodder, is a parasitic plant which belongs to the family Convolvulaceae. It was formerly classified in the family Cuscutaceae.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"High","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Field Dodder"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Cuscuta campestris"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

After the flowering period, cut back stems to promote the plant's next cycle of blooms. If the plant becomes leggy or overgrown, light pruning can encourage a more compact shape. Always use clean, sharp scissors or shears to prevent disease transmission and ensure smooth cuts."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Fringed Bleeding Heart","description":"Dicentra eximia (wild or fringed bleeding-heart, turkey-corn) is a flowering plant with fernlike leaves and oddly shaped flowers native to the Appalachian Mountains. While it can grow in partial shade, limited sunlight may lead to reduced blooming and a less vigorous appearance. Ensuring the right balance of sunlight will result in a lush, flowering carpet of color in spring."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Aubrieta deltoidea primarily involves removing spent flowers to promote further blooming and maintaining shape. After the flowering period in spring, trim back the plant by about half to prevent legginess and to encourage denser growth. This also helps in promoting healthier foliage and further flowering. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13041,"attracts":["Birds","Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Erigeron annuus, commonly known as annual fleabane, prefers moderately moist but well-drained soil. It is relatively drought-tolerant once established. Water the plant deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry somewhat between waterings. During extremely dry periods or hot temperatures, it may require more frequent watering. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot. In container settings, make sure the pots have adequate drainage holes to prevent waterlogging. Adjust watering based on weather conditions and soil moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Annual fleabane thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth and flowering, the plant should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to protect the plant from extreme heat and prevent wilting. If grown in areas with less sunlight, growth may become leggy, and flowering could be reduced. Monitoring the plant in the first few weeks after planting can help determine the best spot for sun exposure, ensuring it gets the right balance for healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Erigeron annuus involves removing spent blooms to encourage more flowering and to prevent unwanted self-seeding. Deadheading can be done regularly throughout the blooming season, simply snipping the flowers off at their base. In late fall, or after the first frost, trim back the entire plant to a few inches above the ground. This helps maintain plant health and improve appearance. Cutting back before seeds are set can also prevent the plant from spreading too aggressively. Regular pruning can help control its growth and prolong the blooming season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"annual fleabane","description":"Erigeron annuus (annual fleabane, daisy fleabane, or eastern daisy fleabane) is a North American plant species in the daisy family.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["annual fleabane"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Erigeron annuus"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12542,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cirsium andersonii, commonly known as Anderson's thistle, prefers well-drained soil and can tolerate periods of drought. It's important not to overwater this plant as it is adapted to dryer environments. Watering should be done sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out completely between each session. If grown in a garden setting, it may benefit from occasional watering during extended dry periods to help it thrive, but overall, maintaining a dry soil condition is preferable for this plant. Be cautious to avoid waterlogged conditions which can lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cirsium andersonii thrives in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight a day. It is adapted to sunny environments, which helps it develop its vibrant blooms and strong stems. While it can tolerate partial shade, too little sunlight can result in leggy growth and reduced flowering. Plant it in an area where it receives morning sun and a bit of afternoon shade if you’re in a particularly hot climate, but ensure that it does not remain in shade for too long, as full sun exposure is optimal for its growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cirsium andersonii should be primarily focused on maintaining its shape and removing any dead or damaged stems. As this plant can become quite prolific, cutting back flower heads after they bloom will prevent self-seeding and unwanted spreading. If you wish to control its size or encourage bushier growth, you can lightly prune in early spring. However, be mindful not to cut back during late autumn to winter as this can expose new growth to freeze damage. Regular pruning will help keep this hardy plant looking tidy and healthy."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Anderson's thistle","description":"Cirsium andersonii is a North American species of thistle known by the common names Anderson's thistle and rose thistle. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12643,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Agrostemma githago, commonly known as corn cockle, prefers moderately moist soil conditions. It's essential to water the plant consistently to maintain slight moisture, especially during dry periods. However, be cautious not to overwater, as this can lead to root rot. It’s best to allow the top layer of the soil to dry out slightly between watering sessions, ensuring good drainage. Established plants are somewhat drought-tolerant, but regular watering will promote lush growth and prolonged flowering. A weekly watering schedule, adjusting based on rainfall and temperature, should suffice in keeping Agrostemma githago healthy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Agrostemma githago thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 hours of direct sun each day for optimal growth and flowering. Position this plant in a location where it receives unfiltered sunlight to stimulate vibrant blooms and healthy foliage. While it can tolerate partial shade, too much shade will result in leggy plants and reduced flower production. Full sun also helps the plant develop strong stems, reducing the risk of flopping or needing support. If planted in containers, make sure it is placed in a bright spot, preferably outdoors, to harness ample sunlight exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Agrostemma githago is essential for maintaining its aesthetic appeal and promoting healthy growth. Deadheading spent flowers is the primary practice, as it encourages the plant to produce more blooms throughout the growing season. This involves pinching or cutting off the faded flowers just above the next set of leaves. Additionally, at the end of the growing season, you should cut the plant back to tidy the garden and prepare for winter. This keeps the plant healthy and may prevent excessive self-seeding, as corn cockle can potentially spread aggressively in favorable conditions."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"corn cockle","description":"Agrostemma githago, the common corn-cockle (also written \"corncockle\" and \"corn cockle\" and known locally simply as \"the corncockle\").","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["corn cockle"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Agrostemma githago"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches regularly to promote good air circulation. You can also trim back excessive growth to keep the plant neat and prevent it from becoming leggy. The best time to prune this plant is in late winter or early spring before the new growth starts. Use clean and sharp pruning shears to make clean cuts, which helps in faster healing and reduces the risk of infections."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"white-margined nightshade","description":"Solanum marginatum is a species of nightshade known by the common names purple African nightshade and white-margined nightshade. The large, distinctive, gray-green leaves are wavy along the edges, woolly on the undersides, and measure up to 18 centimeters long. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12744,"attracts":["Birds","Insects"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Avicennia marina, commonly known as the grey mangrove, requires consistent moisture as it naturally thrives in tidal zones. While it's quite tolerant of salinity and can cope with varied water conditions, maintaining soil moisture is crucial when grown in non-coastal settings. Water the plant regularly to keep the soil moist but not waterlogged. In drier climates or during less frequent tidal events, ensure the plant has access to fresh, brackish water to sustain healthy growth and mimic its natural environment. Overly dry conditions should be avoided to prevent stress and stunted growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Avicennia marina thrives best in full sunlight conditions that mimic its natural coastal and intertidal environments. It can tolerate partial shade, but optimal growth occurs with ample direct sunlight exposure. When cultivating this plant, ensure it receives at least 6-8 hours of sunlight daily to promote strong growth and vibrant foliage. The plant's resilience to full sun also aligns with its high tolerance for warm climates. In regions with intense heat, some afternoon shade or protection from the harshest sunlight may help prevent leaf scorching, though generally it handles full sun well."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Avicennia marina is generally minimal, as it is a hardy species that naturally achieves a good structure. However, light pruning can be beneficial to remove any dead or damaged branches, which helps improve air flow and light penetration within the canopy. This maintenance can also help control its shape and size, especially in ornamental settings or when grown in confined spaces. Prune during the dormant season or late winter to minimize stress on the plant. Avoid excessive pruning as it could hinder the plant's natural resilience and growth patterns."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Grey Mangrove","description":"Avicennia marina, commonly known as grey mangrove or white mangrove, is a species of mangrove tree classified in the plant family Acanthaceae (formerly in the Verbenaceae or Avicenniaceae). As with other mangroves, it occurs in the intertidal zones of estuarine areas.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["East Africa","West Asia","South Asia","South-East Asia","Australia"],"other_name":["Grey Mangrove"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Avicennia marina"],"soil":["Well-drained","Saline"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13740,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Verbena bonariensis prefers evenly moist soil, especially during its growing season. It is moderately drought tolerant once established but should be watered regularly to keep the soil from drying out completely. Be careful not to overwater, as this can lead to root rot. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings in well-draining soil. Reduce watering during the plant's dormancy in winter. Adjust your watering schedule based on local climate and rainfall to avoid excess moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Verbena bonariensis thrives in full sun, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight each day. It is well suited to sunny borders, beds, and open areas where there is plenty of light. Insufficient sunlight can result in spindly growth and reduced flowering. In very hot climates, it may benefit from some afternoon shade to prevent leaf scorch, but generally, the more sun exposure, the better its growth and flower production. Ensure that the location has good air circulation to reduce the risk of powdery mildew."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Verbena bonariensis is essential for maintaining its shape and promoting new growth. Deadheading spent blooms regularly encourages continuous flowering throughout the season. In late fall or early spring, cut back the plant to about 6 inches from the ground to remove any dead or damaged stems and prepare it for the next growing season. This will help encourage bushier growth and more abundant blooming. Regular maintenance pruning helps to control the size and prevent the plant from becoming too leggy."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"purpletop vervain","description":"Verbena bonariensis (purpletop vervain, clustertop vervain, Argentinian vervain, tall verbena, or pretty verbena) is a member of the verbena family cultivated as a flowering annual or herbaceous perennial plant. In USA horticulture, it is also known by the ambiguous names \"purpletop\" (also used for the grass Tridens flavus) and \"South American vervain\" (which can mean any of the numerous species in the genus Verbena occurring in that continent). For the misapplication \"Brazilian verbena\" see below.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South America"],"other_name":["purpletop vervain"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Verbena bonariensis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Regular trimming also encourages more dense foliage, ensuring a healthy, lush appearance."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"wax-leaf ligustrum","description":"Ligustrum japonicum, known as wax-leaf privet or Japanese privet (Japanese: ネズミモチ) is a species of Ligustrum (privet) native to central and southern Japan (Honshū, Shikoku, Kyūshū, Okinawa) and Korea. Adequate sunlight also supports the tree in developing its characteristic broad and spreading canopy, making it an excellent choice for ornamental planting in sunny landscapes."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Delonix regia is essential to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. Additionally, trimming back branches that cross over each other or grow downward helps improve air circulation and sunlight penetration. Limit pruning of the main branches to avoid stressing the tree, but regular light trimming will support a balanced and appealing canopy, characteristic of the umbrella-like shape of a mature Royal Poinciana."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Flamboyant","description":"Delonix regia is a species of flowering plant in the bean family Fabaceae, subfamily Caesalpinioideae. It is noted for its fern-like leaves and flamboyant display of flowers. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12443,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"The Sitka spruce, or Picea sitchensis, prefers well-drained, moist soil. While it is drought-tolerant once established, regular watering is crucial during its early development stages. During the first couple of years after planting, ensure that the soil remains consistently moist but not waterlogged. Water deeply once a week, allowing the water to penetrate to the root system, particularly during extended dry periods or heatwaves. Be cautious about over-watering, especially in heavy clay soils, as this can lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sitka spruce thrives best in full sun, which means it should receive at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily. While it can tolerate part shade, especially in its early years, full exposure to sunlight will ensure optimal growth and health. This plant is particularly well-suited to cooler and moist climates where sunlight is abundant, but the temperatures are not excessively hot. In more shaded conditions, the spruces may grow more slowly and become less dense, making full sun preferable for robust health and growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Picea sitchensis is generally minimal as it naturally forms a conical shape. However, removing dead, damaged, or diseased branches is beneficial and can be done at any time of the year. Instead, it derives water and nutrients by attaching itself to host plants. Therefore, if growing in a controlled environment, ensure the host plants are adequately watered to facilitate dodder growth. Overwatering or underwatering the host could affect the dodder's health indirectly. Maintaining a stable moisture level for the host plant provides the best environment for Cuscuta pacifica to thrive."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cuscuta pacifica favors open, sunny locations where its host plants are thriving. Adequate sunlight ensures the host plants remain vigorous, which in turn sustains the dodder. Aim for a minimum of 6 hours of direct sunlight daily as this condition is ideal for most potential host plants, thus indirectly benefiting the Cuscuta. However, since it is parasitic, dodder can adapt to varying light conditions as long as its host survives and thrives in those conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Cuscuta pacifica involves managing its spread, as it can quickly overtake host plants. Regularly check the plant for excessive growth and clip away any new shoots that appear uncontrollable or encroaching on neighboring vegetation undesirably. Use sharp, sanitized scissors to cut back the dodder to maintain a manageable size and prevent damage or unwarranted infestation on the host plant. Regular pruning also promotes healthier host plants, because it limits the parasitic load."}],"care_level":"Extreme","common_name":"Pacific goldenthread","description":"Cuscuta pacifica is a species of dodder. In natural settings, this plant thrives in areas with low moisture, so mimicking these conditions in a garden setting is crucial. During prolonged periods of drought, provide only occasional watering to maintain plant health, particularly during its growth phase, but ensure the soil has good drainage to prevent waterlogging."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Erigeron aphanactis thrives in full sun, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily to perform optimally. This sun-loving plant grows naturally in open, exposed areas, so ensure it is planted in a spot that receives ample sunlight throughout the day. If grown in partial shade, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. Full sun exposure helps maintain its compact form and encourages prolific flowering. Ensure it's not shaded by larger plantings or structures and that it receives continuous sunlight, especially during its active growing season in the warmer months."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Erigeron aphanactis is generally minimal. It's primarily done to remove spent flowers and any dead or damaged foliage to maintain a neat appearance and encourage a healthy growth cycle. After the flowering season, trim back old flower heads to promote new blooms and prevent unwanted self-seeding. Prune back any stems that appear weak or too leggy to encourage a more compact growth habit. This native wildflower benefits from being left largely untouched, so only prune as necessary, typically in late fall or early winter when the plant is dormant. Ensure tools are clean to prevent disease spread."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"rayless shaggy fleabane","description":"Erigeron aphanactis is a species of flowering plant in the daisy family (Asteraceae) known by the common name rayless daisy,:121 or rayless shaggy fleabane. Ensure good drainage to prevent root rot and allow the soil to dry slightly between waterings, avoiding standing water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Agrostis capillaris thrives in full sun but can tolerate partial shade. Adequate sunlight ensures vigorous growth and optimal color, but provide some protection or extra care during peak summer heat to prevent scorching. In shadier areas, increase the irrigation slightly to compensate for less photosynthesis."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Regular mowing of Agrostis capillaris is essential to encourage dense growth and maintain the appearance of a manicured lawn. The ideal mowing height is between 1.0 and 1.5 inches. Pruning involves removing dead or damaged grass and ensuring that clumps are kept under control. Mow regularly, but never remove more than one-third of the blade length at once to avoid stressing the grass. Scarifying, or dethatching, can be done in the growing season to remove debris and encourage healthy growth. Regular mowing and dethatching promote air circulation and nutrient absorption."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"colonial bent","description":"Agrostis capillaris (common bent, colonial bent, browntop) is a rhizomatous and stoloniferous perennial in the grass family (Poaceae). {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14032,"attracts":["Birds","Squirrels"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Carya tomentosa, commonly known as mockernut hickory, is a drought-tolerant tree that generally requires minimal watering once established. Young trees should be watered regularly to help them establish robust root systems. It is crucial to ensure the soil drains well to prevent waterlogging, as hickories do not thrive in soggy conditions. Mulching around the base can help retain moisture and regulate soil temperature. During particularly dry spells, providing supplemental watering can be beneficial, but it's often unnecessary for mature trees as they access deeper groundwater."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Carya tomentosa thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sun each day to grow optimally. While the tree can tolerate partial shade, full sunlight is essential for the production of strong wood and healthy nuts. In shaded conditions, the growth rate might be slower, and the tree may become leggy and less dense. When choosing a planting spot, consider areas that receive unobstructed sunlight throughout the day to ensure vigorous, healthy growth and abundant nut production."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Carya tomentosa is typically done during the dormant season, in late winter or early spring, before new growth begins. The primary objective is to remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to maintain tree health and promote vigorous growth. It is also important to thin out dense areas to improve air circulation and light penetration. Avoid excessive pruning, as this can stress the tree and reduce its vigor. Cut branches at the branch collar using clean, sharp tools to minimize damage and promote faster healing."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"mockernut","description":"Carya tomentosa, (mockernut hickory, mockernut, white hickory, whiteheart hickory, hognut, bullnut) is a tree in the Juglandaceae or walnut family. The most abundant of the hickories, common in the eastern half of the US, it is long lived, sometimes reaching the age of 500 years. A straight-growing hickory, a high percentage of its wood is used for products where strength, hardness, and flexibility are needed. The wood makes an excellent fuelwood, as well.","family":null,"flower_color":"Greenish-yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["mockernut"],"pest_susceptibility":["Hickory bark beetle","Aphids","Canker disease"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Carya tomentosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13144,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Helenium amarum, commonly known as bitterweed, requires moderate watering. It is drought-tolerant once established, making it a low-maintenance option for gardens. Water the plant deeply but infrequently to encourage deep root growth. Allow the top few inches of soil to dry out completely between watering sessions to prevent overwatering, which can lead to root rot. During prolonged dry spells, increase watering frequency, especially in sandy or well-drained soils. In contrast, reduce watering in cooler months when the plant's growth slows down. Always ensure proper drainage as excessively wet soil is detrimental to this species."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Helenium amarum thrives in full sunlight and requires at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight every day. This plant is adapted to sunny, open locations and performs best when exposed to abundant light. Insufficient sunlight may lead to leggy growth and reduced bloom quantity. While it can tolerate partial shade, optimal flowering and growth are achieved under full sun conditions. If growing indoors or in a shaded area, consider supplementing with artificial grow lights to mimic natural sunlight. This will help ensure the plant receives adequate energy for flowering and overall health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Helenium amarum helps maintain its shape and encourages bushier growth. Regularly remove faded flowers to extend the blooming period; this process is known as deadheading. In early spring, trim back any dead or damaged stems to promote healthy new growth. During the growing season, light pruning can be done to control the plant’s height and encourage branching. At the end of the flowering season, cut back the plant to about one-third of its height to prepare it for winter dormancy. However, avoid excessive pruning, as this can stress the plant and reduce flowering."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Bitterweed","description":"Helenium amarum is a species of annual herb in the daisy family known by the common names yellowdicks, yellow sneezeweed, fiveleaf sneezeweed, and bitter sneezeweed. It is native to much of the south-central United States (Texas, Oklahoma, Louisiana, Arkansas, New Mexico) and northern Mexico (Chihuahua, Coahuila), and it is present elsewhere in North America, Australia, and the West Indies as an introduced species.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Bitterweed"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Helenium amarum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy","Clay"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13840,"attracts":["birds","mammals"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Quercus marilandica, or the Blackjack Oak, is a drought-tolerant tree that requires a moderate watering regimen. When first planted, it should be watered regularly to establish a strong root system. Ensuring the soil is well-draining will prevent waterlogging, which can be detrimental. Once established, the tree can handle drier conditions and only needs watering during prolonged dry periods. Over-watering should be avoided to prevent root rot. Water deeply but infrequently to encourage deep root growth, ideally letting the top inch of soil dry out before watering again."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Quercus marilandica thrives best in full sunlight, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. It can tolerate partial shade, but full sun exposure ensures optimal growth and development. When selecting a planting location, ensure the tree is placed in a spot where it can receive unobstructed sunlight throughout the day. Full sunlight supports its robust growth pattern and enhances its drought tolerance. In shaded areas, the Blackjack Oak may grow more slowly and develop a less dense canopy, impacting its overall health and vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Quercus marilandica should be done minimally, as excessive pruning can harm the tree's natural shape and vigor. It's best to prune in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Focus on removing any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to improve air circulation and light penetration through the canopy. Avoid removing more than one-third of the live crown at a time. Prune to maintain a strong central leader, and be cautious not to prune oak trees during the growing season to prevent oak wilt transmission."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"blackjack oak","description":"Quercus marilandica (blackjack oak) is a small oak, one of the red oak group Quercus sect. Lobatae. It is native to the eastern and central United States, from Long Island to Florida, west as far as Texas, Oklahoma, and Nebraska. There are reports of a few isolated populations in southern Michigan, but these appear to represent introductions.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["blackjack oak"],"pest_susceptibility":["fungal diseases"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Quercus marilandica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy","Clay"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ensure that the soil is consistently moist, but well-drained to prevent waterlogging. Once established, the plant becomes more drought tolerant, requiring less frequent watering. In general, water the plant deeply once or twice a week, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between watering. It's important to adjust the watering schedule based on local climate conditions and rainfall. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so always monitor soil moisture levels."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Phacelia heterophylla thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth and blooming. This plant can tolerate partial shade, but flower production might be reduced in less sunny locations. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can prevent the foliage from scorching. Ensuring adequate sunlight not only promotes vibrant blooms but also aids in the plant's overall health. Position the plant where it gets morning sunlight and some protection during the hottest part of the day if possible."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Phacelia heterophylla is generally minimal, but occasional trimming can encourage bushier growth and prolong blooming. Deadheading spent flowers can help prevent the plant from self-seeding uncontrollably and maintain a tidy appearance. If the plant becomes leggy or overgrown, light pruning can be done in early spring before new growth begins. Use clean, sharp shears to cut back any damaged or diseased stems to promote healthy growth. Overall, this plant requires little maintenance when it comes to pruning, making it a low-maintenance choice for many gardeners."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"virgate scorpionweed","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Western North America"],"other_name":["virgate scorpionweed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Phacelia heterophylla"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Once the plant enters dormancy in the summer, significantly reduce watering, allowing the soil to dry out between watering sessions. Overwatering during dormancy should be avoided, as it can lead to bulb rot. Adjust your watering routine based on rainfall and the plant's environmental conditions. Containers should have drainage holes to prevent standing water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Calochortus fimbriatus thrives in full sun to light shade environments. In areas with hot climates, a location that provides morning sun and afternoon shade can help prevent the plant from overheating. Ensure the plant is not in complete shade, as this will inhibit flowering and weaken the plant overall."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Calochortus fimbriatus is relatively straightforward. You should remove spent flowers after they bloom to prevent the plant from putting energy into seed production, which can encourage more vigorous growth and flowering. Also, remove any yellowing or damaged foliage to maintain plant health and appearance. This helps to keep the area tidy and prepares the plant for the next growth cycle."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Late-blooming Mariposa Lily","description":"Calochortus fimbriatus is a California species of flowering plant in the lily family known by the common name late-blooming mariposa lily. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13043,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Erigeron bonariensis, also known as Flaxleaf Fleabane, prefers well-drained soil and does not require frequent watering. It is quite drought-tolerant once established, making it ideal for xeriscaping or low-water gardens. During the growing season, water it moderately, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering should be avoided, as this can lead to root rot. Additionally, reducing watering frequency in the cooler months can help prevent overmoist conditions. It thrives better in lower humidity environments, so ensure good air circulation if grown indoors or in humid areas."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Erigeron bonariensis thrives best in full sun, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily. This light requirement aids in robust growth and plentiful blooming throughout its flowering season. While it can tolerate partial shade, too much shade may result in lanky growth and reduced flowering. If grown indoors, place it in a bright, sunny window, preferably south-facing, to mimic its outdoor sunlight needs. Providing adequate sunlight not only supports optimal growth but also enhances the plant’s overall resilience to pests and diseases."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not usually necessary for Erigeron bonariensis, but it can help manage its growth and encourage bushier plants. Deadheading, or removing spent flowers, will prevent the plant from self-seeding excessively and can promote prolonged blooming. If the plant becomes too leggy or messy, it can be trimmed back by about one-third, which usually stimulates fresh, bushy growth. Major pruning is best done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Throughout the season, regularly remove any dead, damaged, or diseased stems to maintain plant health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Flax-leaved Horseweed","description":"Erigeron bonariensis is a species of Erigeron, found throughout the tropics and subtropics as a pioneer plant; its precise native origin is unknown, but most likely Central America or South America. It has become naturalized in many other regions. Common names include flax-leaf fleabane, wavy-leaf fleabane, Argentine fleabane, and hairy fleabane.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South America"],"other_name":["Flax-leaved Horseweed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Erigeron bonariensis"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12944,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cuscuta subinclusa, commonly known as a dodder, is a parasitic plant that derives its water and nutrients from host plants rather than the soil. Thus, traditional watering methods are not applicable. This plant thrives in environments where its host plants are healthy and well-watered. Ensure that the host plants receive adequate water to support both themselves and the dodder. In cultivated settings, maintain a regular watering schedule for host plants to prevent their stress and ensure optimal growth conditions for the dodder."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cuscuta subinclusa typically thrives in bright, open areas with ample sunlight. As a parasitic plant, it prefers conditions that support the growth of its host plants which usually means full sun to partial shade. Ensure the host plants are situated in areas where they can receive abundant sunlight, which will, in turn, support the growth and vitality of the dodder. Avoid placing host plants in excessively shaded areas as this could impact their health and subsequently affect the dodder."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Managing Cuscuta subinclusa involves careful pruning to keep its parasitic growth in check. Regularly inspect host plants and trim back dodder growth to prevent it from overwhelming and excessively draining the host. Use sterilized pruning tools to cut dodder stems close to the host’s surface without damaging the host plant itself. This method helps in mitigating any aggressive spread and potential harm to the overall vegetation health in the environment."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Canyon Dodder","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"High","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Canyon Dodder"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal diseases"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Cuscuta subinclusa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Instead, if cultivating for observation or study, it is important to maintain a humid environment to mimic its natural habitat. Ensure the substrate around this fungus remains moist but not waterlogged. Always avoid direct watering to prevent damage to the delicate fruiting bodies, as excess moisture can lead to rot or hinder spore dispersal."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Calostoma cinnabarinum naturally thrives in shaded, forested environments where direct sunlight is minimal. When cultivating or observing this fungus, it’s crucial to replicate these conditions by providing a shaded area with indirect light. Direct sunlight can dry out the fruiting bodies and negatively impact growth, so a dappled light setting, similar to the forest floor, is ideal. Keeping it in an area where it receives diffused light will help maintain the necessary humidity and growth conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable for Calostoma cinnabarinum as it is a fungus, not a plant. Key care involves monitoring its growth environment rather than trimming. Ensure it has the right conditions—adequate moisture, organic matter in the substrate, and shade. If in a controlled study, simply remove decayed specimens or any surrounding debris that might hinder its growth. Pruning in the traditional sense doesn't apply, but managing its environment is crucial for optimal development."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"stalked puffball-in-aspic","description":"Calostoma cinnabarinum is a species of gasteroid fungus in the family Sclerodermataceae, and is the type species of the genus Calostoma. It is known by several common names, including stalked puffball-in-aspic and gelatinous stalked-puffball. The fruit body has a distinctive color and overall appearance, featuring a layer of yellowish jelly surrounding a bright red, spherical head approximately 2 centimeters (0.8 in) in diameter atop a red or yellowish brown spongy stipe 1.5 to 4 cm (0.6 to 2 in)...","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["stalked puffball-in-aspic"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Calostoma cinnabarinum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Partial shade can be tolerated, but results in a less robust appearance compared to those grown with full sun exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning or mowing of Agrostis gigantea should be conducted based on its use and desired appearance. In lawn settings, regular mowing keeps the grass tidy, typically at a height of 1.5 to 3 inches. In meadow or naturalized areas, pruning once a year in late winter or early spring is often sufficient. Remove dead or unwanted plant material to encourage dense, new growth and to prevent the buildup of thatch. If you want to keep it ornamental, trim regularly to maintain shape, and to control spread in garden settings."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"redtop","description":"Agrostis gigantea, known by its common names black bent and redtop, is a perennial grass of the Agrostis genus.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["redtop"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Rust"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Agrostis gigantea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

When grown indoors, it should be placed in a spot that receives indirect light. If natural light is insufficient, consider supplementing with artificial grow lights. In shaded outdoor plantings, it maintains its lush, green appearance, while exposure to excessive sunlight can lead to browning or drying of foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ruscus aculeatus is relatively straightforward and involves removing any dead, damaged, or yellowing stems and leaves to maintain its appearance and health. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to make clean cuts just above a node or lateral branch. This encourages denser growth and helps rejuvenate the plant over time. Avoid excessive pruning as it can stress the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"butcher's-broom","description":"Ruscus aculeatus, known as butcher's-broom, is a low evergreen Eurasian shrub, with flat shoots known as cladodes that give the appearance of stiff, spine-tipped leaves.
